security_audit.summary: All 66 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The skill is a legitimate spreadsheet manipulation tool. External commands (subprocess.run) only invoke LibreOffice for formula recalculation with hardcoded arguments. File system access is for LibreOffice configuration in standard directories. URLs are standard license references. 'C2 keywords' on SKILL.md:121 are Excel cell references (C2 column), not C2 malware. System reconnaissance patterns refer to Excel error type names (#REF!, #DIV/0!), not system commands.

content.user_title: Create and edit Excel spreadsheets with formulas
content.value_statement: Working with Excel files requires knowledge of formulas, formatting, and data analysis. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for creating spreadsheets, performing calculations, and analyzing data with professional standards.
actual_capabilities: Create new Excel spreadsheets with formulas and professional formatting
Read and analyze data from Excel files using pandas
Edit existing spreadsheets while preserving formulas and styles
Recalculate all formulas in a spreadsheet using LibreOffice
Apply industry-standard color coding for financial models
Detect and fix Excel formula errors (#REF!, #DIV/0!, #VALUE!)
limitations: Requires LibreOffice installed for formula recalculation
Large files may require read_only or write_only modes for performance
Formula recalculation is performed through external LibreOffice process
Complex VBA macros are not supported

use_cases.title: Build financial models
use_cases.description: Create discounted cash flow models and valuation spreadsheets with proper color coding and formula standards

use_cases.title: Export analysis results
use_cases.description: Analyze data with pandas and export results to formatted Excel workbooks for stakeholder reports

use_cases.title: Manage spreadsheet data
use_cases.description: Read, modify, and update Excel files while preserving formulas and existing formatting conventions

prompt_templates.title: Create simple spreadsheet
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new Excel file called sales_report.xlsx. Add a worksheet with monthly sales data in columns A and B. Include a formula in column C that calculates the year-over-year growth percentage. Apply currency formatting.

prompt_templates.title: Analyze existing data
prompt_templates.prompt: Read quarterly_data.xlsx and analyze the trends. Calculate average, minimum, and maximum values for each quarter. Add a summary section at the top.

prompt_templates.title: Build financial model
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 5-year projection model in projection.xlsx. Use separate assumption cells for growth rate, margin, and tax rate. Apply industry-standard color coding.

prompt_templates.title: Recalculate formulas
prompt_templates.prompt: Recalculate all formulas in financial_model.xlsx using recalc.py. Check for errors and fix any #REF! or #DIV/0! issues by correcting cell references.

output_examples.input: Create a budget spreadsheet with monthly categories and a total formula
output: Created budget.xlsx with monthly budget categories
Column A: Category names (Housing, Food, Transportation, etc.)
Columns B-G: Monthly amounts in currency format
Yellow highlighting on assumption cells (inflation rate: 3%)

output_examples.input: Analyze sales data and create a summary report
output: Calculated totals: Q1 $1.2M, Q2 $1.4M, Q3 $1.3M, Q4 $1.5M
Created summary sheet with year-over-year growth comparison
Added trend chart showing monthly performance
Formatted all currency cells with $#,##0 format

best_practices: Always use Excel formulas instead of hardcoded values to keep spreadsheets dynamic and updateable
Place assumptions in separate cells with clear labels and use cell references in formulas
Apply consistent formatting and color coding that matches your organization standards
anti_patterns: Calculating values in Python and hardcoding the results instead of using Excel formulas
Using absolute values in formulas instead of references to assumption cells
Opening files with data_only=True and saving them, which permanently deletes formulas

faq.question: What Excel file formats are supported?
faq.answer: Supports .xlsx, .xlsm, .csv, and .tsv formats for reading and writing spreadsheets.

faq.question: What is the formula recalculation limit?
faq.answer: The script recalculates all formulas but has a configurable timeout (default 30 seconds) for very large files.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with other tools?
faq.answer: Import pandas for data analysis and openpyxl for formatting. Use load_workbook to edit existing files.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Files are processed locally. The skill only accesses files you explicitly specify. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why are my formulas showing as text instead of calculating?
faq.answer: openpyxl preserves formulas but does not calculate them. Run recalc.py to compute all formula values using LibreOffice.

faq.question: How is this different from using Excel directly?
faq.answer: This skill enables programmatic spreadsheet operations through Claude. It combines pandas analysis with Excel formatting and formulas.
